results.title: Sustainable Ouyen
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: Several years ago a group of Ouyen Primary School students petitioned their local council to adopt a community-recycling program. To everybody’s surprise the council not only provided an unprecedented household recycling service but did so at a loss. Since that time the community has launched a number of forward thinking initiatives with solar power, sustainable agriculture and improved water usage. Whether it’s the Ouyen Football Club, High School or local farmers, there’s an understanding that sustainable practices must be employed now in order for future Ouyen generations to benefit.

results.title: Sunraysia Ukulele Network
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: An unlikely group of people come together once a month to share their love of the Ukulele. They meet on the last Sunday of each month at a local landmark called The Old Cottage where they play the uke and have a sing-a-long. Everyone is welcome, from beginners to more experienced players, the door is always open.

results.title: ACMI in the regions: Stories from Maffra
results.creator_credit: Kim Montgomery, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: Vox pops with the locals of Maffra. The township of Maffra in the Wellington Shire, southeast of Victoria, is home to approximately 4000 people and was chosen to host the third annual Small Towns Summit from 26 to 27 August 2009. The summit is an initiative of the Small Towns Victoria Program funded by Regional Development Victoria, organised by the Municipal Association of Victoria. The program aims to broadly address the issues facing small rural towns in Victoria.

group_works.title: The Milky way = Dairy farming in Maffra
Young voices of Maffra = Future leaders : Young voices of Maffra

results.title: Young voices of Maffra = Future leaders : Young voices of Maffra
results.brief_description:
This film focuses on the young people of Maffra. Eight students from Maffra Secondary College were interviewed, representing all the year levels, and asked to talk about life in a regional town, their hopes for the future and issues that affect them and their world.
The end result is a portrait of young rural Victorians who are thoughtful and engaging, with concerns about the environment, world politics and the survival of small towns.

results.title: Welcome to Maffra
results.brief_description: This film starts with Darren McCubbin, the Mayor of the Wellington Shire, welcoming the audience to Maffra. Darren explains that we are about to visit some of the places and meet some of the people that make Maffra a unique place to live. The film features the Geoff Webster Centre, the Gippsland Vehicle Collection, the Maffra Gymnastics Club, the George Gray Centre, Wallaby Rise Restaurant, Cambrai Backpacker Hostel and Jenny McDavitt an Alpaca farmer and Ferial Zikerman who is now internationally known for her Maffra Cheese.

results.title: The Milky way = Dairy farming in Maffra
results.brief_description: This film showcases farming in the Maffra region and features six farmers who are leading the way in innovation and new farming technologies. Alan Clyne and his son Allister together with Robert White and John White are involved in the Herd Improvement initiative. Graeme Anderson and his son Ross are making the most of new irrigation techniques. Max Warren introduces his Robotic Dairy, the first ever to be used in Australia.

results.title: Ouyen's Roxy Theatre
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: The Roxy Theatre in Ouyen was under threat of becoming an abandoned ruin until the community stepped in to save it. Originally opened in 1936, it eventually became one of the only tropical theatres in the southern region of Australia but was closed in 1971 due to the actions of rowdy youths (according to local myth). After 36 years of closure, Jenny Heaslip took on the challenge of restoring the theatre and rallied over 250 local volunteers to help her. It is now an integral meeting point for the people of Ouyen not only because of fortnightly film screenings, but for community events, launches and celebrations. Run on a shoestring budget The Roxy continues to rely upon volunteers and community fundraising to stay alive.

results.title: Marion of Colignan
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: Marion Peters loves living on the land. Despite having the opportunity of establishing a life in the city, she returned to her hometown to raise a family with her husband Geoff on a 12-hectare organic farm that they developed from scratch. Having overcome droughts, hailstorms and the large financial strain of maintaining a farm, Marion feels that things are finally looking up, with a bumper harvest of apples and promising yields of avocadoes and lemons. Marion is heavily involved in giving back to her community, pivotal in fundraising and ensuring community activities are maintained in a small town with a small population. She believes that it is vital for locals to stay involved and active within their own community.

results.title: YCDco : a story of community support
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description: When the only service station in town was under threat of closure, seven local people got together and decided to do something positive about it. They formed the Yackandandah Community Development Company Pty Ltd - YCDCo. To build a new fuel outlet, a share offer was launched to the community and over $400,000 was raised. Now almost every one in Yackandandah is a shareholder and receives a dividend each year. But the most valuable dividends are not monetary. YCDco contributes funds to the local newspaper, is integral to the Yack Folk Festival and has funded many local schools, sports and community groups.
